column1: I had been blessed, three years earlier, to find a house and a housekeeper in one, when one of my aged college dons died and her lifelong companion fell on hard times. Miss Pidgeon understood the conflicting urges of comfort and privacy, and provided the first without threatening the second. She lived in what had once been the servants' quarters, separated by a small garden from the house proper, and with so much as a few hours' warning, I would
column3: to find the icebox filled with milk and essentials, a fire laid (if not actually burning), newspapers beside the settee, and never more sign of an actual person than a brief note of welcome on the kitchen table. She never made the mistake of tidying my papers, and she had an unexpectedly good eye for who might be an intruder and who looked like one of the owner's odd friends.

column1: Anna Gardie's nearly half decade of fame came at the height of refugee stage success, and she demonstrated her talent for transforming the misfortunes of slave revolution into stage celebrity. Newspaper reports signal the beginning of her US stage career during Philadelphia's 1794 spring theater season, when she appeared at Thomas Wignell's New Theatre in La forêt noire, a French pantomime. Advertisements billed her as newly
column3: from the Theatre at Paris,  even though, by all accounts, she had most recently come from Saint Domingue (" New Theatre "). Whether by choice or not, Gardie almost always performed nonspeaking roles, usually as a dancer and pantomimist. She also occasionally sang French songs, and her greatest American success (judging by its frequency in her repertoire) seems to have been as Columbine, the nonspeaking female lead in the winter holiday season's harlequinades.

column3: before starting time, you could go down to the track and examine the animals. Sometimes a horse had been worked too hard in practice, and you could notice it before the race began, see it in the creature's face, the moisture around his eyes. " It's like insurance, " my father said. " You try to guess the odds, then you decide. "

column1: My dearest love, Please do not abandon me. The only solace that I can find is the hope that you will mourn for the return that I can not promise. Thinking of you, I am unable to sleep. column3: safely for Passover, and I can report that Pascal and Seraphine are in good health. Now that my travel has ended, I have the luxury of applying markings to scroll. Far apart as we are, my intent is to begin each day of this week with you. I picture you listening to my letter and thus pretend we are in conversation. column1: She was glad that she had insisted on making an early start, for this would allow her plenty of time to see something of the countryside and the people as she went along. column3: looking fairly fresh, she had decided to spend three days over her journey. The first day she had driven from Lagos to Ogunba, a distance of about one hundred and fifty miles, and had stayed the night at the Anglican Mission. Now, on the second day, she had roughly one hundred and eighty miles to go before she arrived at Kagiri, a town in the very heart of the country.

column1: Dinner at elBulli is a dazzling blend of cuisine, art and science, an event in and of itself. Few of the dishes are readily identifiable. column1: The first time I saw the Mercedes-Benz star revolving over Europa Center, West Berlin's triumphant commercial hub, I knew I was home. I had a room in a hotel near the main West Berlin station. I didn't even turn on the light as I tossed in my bag. I hit the heavy-named streets, delight in my stride. You would have thought I'd
column3: in Venice. But I'd read quite a bit about how the not-old-for-Europe structures of West Berlin, stripped of decoration, felt squeezed by postwar functionalism. I pranced to the central shopping mall. West Berlin was the outpost of Western prosperity, the floating island of neon and pleasure deep inside Communist territory. This was its core.
column9: COCA; 2017; Black Deutschland; Darryl Pinckney; FIC: Black Deutschland
